title.value: Predicting the probability distribution of bus travel time to measure the reliability of public transport services
title.justification: The title directly reflects the main focus of the research, which is about predicting the probability distribution of bus travel time to measure public transport reliability.
title.quote: Predicting the probability distribution of bus travel time to measure the reliability of public transport services

extractions.description: This paper empirically evaluates probabilistic models for predicting the conditional probability density function of bus travel time to assess public transport reliability.

type.justification: The study involves empirical comparisons of various probabilistic models on a dataset to measure their performance.
type.quote: This work empirically compares probabilistic models for the prediction of the conditional probability density function (PDF) of the travel time.

name.justification: The paper focuses on public transport reliability, which falls under the transportation research field.
name.quote: An important aspect of the quality of a public transport service is its reliability, which is defined as the invariability of the service attributes.

name.justification: The study involves probabilistic models for predicting bus travel time.
name.quote: This work empirically compares probabilistic models for the prediction of the conditional probability density function (PDF) of the travel time.

name.justification: The paper addresses challenges in measuring the reliability of public transport services.
name.quote: This work aims at providing tools to measure, and eventually improve, the reliability of one of the outputs of the service planning phase, namely vehicle schedules.

name.justification: The k-nearest neighbors method with a log-logistic distribution is identified as a specific model achieving the best results.
name.quote: A similarity-based density estimation model using a k-nearest neighbors method and a log-logistic distribution predicted the best estimate of the true conditional PDF of the travel time.

is_contributed.justification: This model was part of the new insights and findings discussed, showcasing its effectiveness in reducing errors.
is_contributed.quote: This model reduced the mean squared error of the expected secondary delay by approximately 9% compared to the benchmark model, namely a random forest.

is_executed.justification: The model was implemented as part of the comparison efforts described in the study.
is_executed.quote: A similarity-based density estimation model using a k-nearest neighbors method and a log-logistic distribution predicted the best estimate

is_compared.justification: The model's performance was compared with other models such as random forest.
is_compared.quote: This model reduced the mean squared error of the expected secondary delay by approximately 9% compared to the benchmark model, namely a random forest.

referenced_paper_title.justification: No specific reference paper title provided for this model.

name.justification: Random Forest is mentioned as the benchmark model used for comparison in the study.
name.quote: This model reduced the mean squared error of the expected secondary delay by approximately 9% compared to the benchmark model, namely a random forest.

is_contributed.justification: Random forest was used as a benchmark model, not a new contribution.
is_contributed.quote: compared to the benchmark model, namely a random forest.

is_executed.justification: The random forest model was executed as part of the benchmark process in the study.
is_executed.quote: compared to the benchmark model, namely a random forest.

is_compared.justification: The random forest model served as a baseline for comparison with other models.
is_compared.quote: compared to the benchmark model, namely a random forest.

referenced_paper_title.justification: No specific reference paper title provided for this model.

name.justification: The dataset consists of more than 41,000 trips and 50 bus routes of the city of Montréal.
name.quote: a dataset of more than 41,000 trips and 50 bus routes of the city of Montréal.

referenced_paper_title.justification: No specific reference paper title is provided for the dataset.
